questions.uddipok: The pie chart below shows the sources of air pollution in a city. Describe the pie chart in 150 words. You should make comparison where necessary.

sub_questions.explanation:
The pie chart displays the various sources of air pollution in a city, highlighting five key contributors. Vehicles are by far the most significant source, accounting for 60% of total air pollution. This indicates a heavy reliance on private and commercial transportation, possibly due to limited public transport infrastructure. Industry is the second-largest contributor at 18% , reflecting emissions from factories and manufacturing units. Power plants contribute 13% , suggesting that electricity generation—likely from fossil fuels—is another major pollutant. Waste disposal activities are responsible for 3% , while heating or using gas contributes nothing ( 0% ), showing negligible or highly controlled emissions in that category.
The disparity is stark: vehicles alone contribute more than all other sources combined, underscoring the urgent need for cleaner transport alternatives and stricter vehicular emission controls. In contrast, waste disposal and gas usage have a minimal impact, suggesting these are not major areas of concern. Targeted interventions in transport and industry could significantly improve air quality.

questions.uddipok:
Read the following stem as the opening of a story and complete it.
Once a golden necklace was lost in a rich man's house. A few servants worked in that house. Naturally, it was suspected that any one of the servants had stolen the necklace. The rich man, unwilling to report the matter to the authorities, decided to resolve it himself..... ………

sub_questions.explanation:
Once a golden necklace was lost in a rich man's house. A few servants worked in that house. Naturally, it was suspected that any one of the servants had stolen the necklace. The rich man, unwilling to report the matter to the authorities, decided to resolve it himself.
He called all the servants together and calmly said, “I know one of you has taken the necklace, but I do not want to punish anyone unfairly. I will give you each a stick. All these sticks are of the same length. Take them home and bring them back tomorrow. The thief’s stick will grow by an inch overnight.”
The servants were surprised but took the sticks and returned to their rooms. That night, the guilty servant could not sleep. He was terrified that his stick would grow, revealing his crime. So, out of fear, he cut an inch off his stick, hoping to avoid suspicion.
The next day, all the servants returned with their sticks. The rich man collected them and carefully measured each one. One stick was shorter by exactly an inch.
The rich man smiled and turned to the servant holding the shorter stick. “You are the thief,” he said calmly. “The sticks were ordinary. None of them were going to grow. But your fear betrayed you.”
Caught and ashamed, the servant confessed to the theft. The rich man, though saddened, forgave him but dismissed him from service, reminding everyone that honesty and trust are more valuable than gold.
Moral: A guilty conscience will always reveal the truth.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you have a friend named Sufol. Write an email to you friend about the duties and responsibilities of a good citizen.

sub_questions.explanation:

Subject: Duties and responsibilities of a good citizen
Dear Sufol,
I hope you're doing well! Today, I want to talk to you about being a good citizen. It's really important, isn't it? A major duty of a good citizen is to be kind and helpful to others. We should always try to be nice to people and help them when they need it. Another responsibility is to follow the rules. That means, we should listen to our teachers, parents, and elders. We should also follow the laws of our country. Taking care of our environment is also part of being a good citizen. We can pick up trash, recycle, and save water to help keep our planet clean and healthy. If we all do these things, we can make our community and our world a better place for living. Let me know about your thoughts and ideas about it.
Your ever,
Tahfim

questions.uddipok:
Write a summary of the following passage:
My name is Amerigo. I am 13 years old and I live on the street alone. My mother, who is separated from my father, doesn't want me. She told me to go away Now she is married to another man. My father lives very far away. I want to go to him, but he won't take me either. I begged him to send me some money so that I could buy a bus ticket. I am still waiting. He has not answered: The streets are now my home. Sometimes I find work. I used to collect trash and sell it to a vendor. I stopped doing that after I had a serious infection and a doctor told me to stay away from the trash dump. Once I worked for an ice-cream shop owner and sold ice-cream on the beach. But I got no money in return. The owner of the shop gave me something to eat, and let me sleep in his hut at night. The work was difficult and painful. The ice-cream box is quite heavy when it is full. I had to walk for hours, offering my ice-cream to whoever wanted to buy.. There were days when I could not even sell one ice-cream. In a way, I am lucky because I am alive. My friends who work sorting rubbish in dumps often suffer from serious diseases. One of them was recently killed after he fell into a hole that opened up in the pile of trash. Many of us work for 10 to 12 hours, and get so little in return that we can't even buy food.

sub_questions.explanation: The passage follows the story of Amerigo, a 13-year-old boy who lives alone on the streets after being rejected by both his mother and father. His mother sent him away, and his father, who lives far away, has not responded to his pleas for help. Amerigo survives by finding occasional work, such as collecting and selling trash, despite the health risks involved. He once worked for an ice-cream shop but received no money, only food and a place to sleep. Despite the hardships, Amerigo considers himself fortunate to be alive, unlike some of his friends who have suffered serious illnesses or even death from their work in trash dumps. Many like him work long hours for minimal pay, struggling to afford basic necessities like food.

questions.uddipok:
Write a summary of the following passage :

Sheikh Kamal knew that there is no shortcut to success. He groomed himself up as a young man who earned success by dint of perseverance and commitment. When the Pakistan military began its genocide in Bangladesh, he joined the Liberation War and received military training at Camp Murtee located at the Himalayan foothills in India. The tall young man who carried himself with dignity and possessed remarkable traits of leadership became the ADC of General Ataul Goni, Osmani, the Commander in Chief of Bangladesh Armed Forces during the Liberation War. After Independence, Sheikh Kamal could, easily remain in Bangladesh Army and pass a secure life but he preferred to engage himself in country building and organizing the young forces to that end, Journalist Syed Ishtiaq Rezi in one of his columns 'Ekjon Sheikh Kamal' in Bangla Tribune rightly says that the unique qualities of Sheikh Kamal's character, especially his wholehearted involvement in sports and culture are never seen in any son or daughter of any President, Prime Minister or High Officials in Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation: Sheikh Kamal exemplified perseverance and commitment, earning success through hard work. He joined the Liberation War during the Pakistan military's genocide in Bangladesh, receiving military training in India and serving as ADC to General Osmani. After independence, instead of pursuing a secure military career, he focused on nation-building and youth organization. Renowned for his involvement in sports and culture, his unique qualities distinguished him from other political figures' offspring in Bangladesh, as noted by journalist Syed Ishtiaq Rezi

questions.uddipok:
Write down the summary of the following poem:-
Hold fast to dreams
For if dreams die
Life is a broken-winged bird
That cannot fly.
Hold fast to dreams
For when dreams go
Life is a barren field
Frozen with snow.

sub_questions.explanation: The poem underscores the importance of holding or fostering a dream since life without dream is meaningless and it loses its true purpose. The poet compares such dreamless life with a 'broken-winged bird', which is unable to fly to reach its destination. In addition, the poet compares a life void of dream with a 'barren field' which is covered with frozen snow. Indeed, we must cherish a dream to be súccessful in life.

questions.uddipok:
Put the following parts of the story in correct order to make the whole story. Only the corresponding 7 numbers of the sentences need to be written:
(i) Sheikh Russel was named after Bangabandhu's favorite writer, renowned philosopher and Nobel laureate, Bertrand Russell, by Bangabandhu himself and Mother Sheikh Fazilatunnesa Mujib.
(ii) He had to face the harsh cruelty of life from the age of one and half, when he had to visit Dhaka Central Jail and Dhaka Cantonment just to meet his beloved father.
(iii) Youngest of the family, his world revolved around his father Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, mother Sheikh Fazilatunnesa Mujib, and elder siblings.
(iv) In 1971, Russel and his family, including his mother and two sisters, were imprisoned in a house in Dhanmondi.
(v) From cruelty, life soon became merciless and he was assassinated along with his family members in a
domestic and foreign conspiracy in the night of 15 August, 1975.
(vi) Sheikh Russel, the youngest son of the Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, was born on 18 October 1964 at the historical Bangabandhu Bhaban.
(vii) Very active and playful from a very early age, he was light of the family.
(viii) When he was released on December 16, 1971, along with his family, he came out of the house saying 'Joy Bangla'.
(ix) He would never want to leave his father during his prison visits. He used to be very upset when he had to leave.
(x) However, life didn't remain playful.

sub_questions.explanation:
(vi)→(i) →(vii)→(x)→ (ii)→(ix)→ (iv)→ (viii) → (iii) → (v)
Sheikh Russel, the youngest son of the Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, was born on 18 October 1964 at the historical Bangabandhu Bhaban. Sheikh Russel was named after Bangabandhu's favorite writer, renowned philosopher and Nobel laureate, Bertrand Russell, by Bangabandhu himself and Mother Sheikh Fazilatunnesa Mujib. Very active and playful from a very early age, he was light of the family. However, life didn't remain playful. He had to face the harsh cruelty of life from the age of one and half, when he had to visit Dhaka Central Jail and Dhaka Cantonment just to meet his beloved father. He would never want to leave his father during his prison visits. He used to be very upset when he had to leave. In 1971, Russel and his family, including his mother and two sisters, were imprisoned in a house on Dhanmondi. When he was released on December 16, 1971, along with his family, he came out of the house saying 'Joy Bangla.' Youngest of the family, his world revolved around his father Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, mother Sheikh Fazilatunnesa Mujib and elder siblings. From cruelty, life soon became merciless and he was assassinated along with his family members in a domestic and foreign conspiracy on the night of 15 August, 1975.
